This week, we are focusing on the topic of **CONNECTION**.

Connecting with your child and spending quality time together makes a big difference to their development.

This week, we are focusing on the topic of **CONNECTION**.

rows.text_1: **CONNECTING** with our children is not always easy!

text_1.eng: **CONNECTING** with our children is not always easy!

media_title.eng: Listen to the audio to learn more.

media_transcript.eng: As caregivers, we all spend time doing things with our children, but giving them our full attention is not always easy. We all face distractions and challenges that make it difficult to spend quality time with our children. When we feel stressed or when our children are being difficult, it can be even harder to find the time and energy to connect with them.

rows.text_1:
How to **CONNECT**?

Join your child in their world!

text_1.eng:
How to **CONNECT**?

Join your child in their world!

media_title.eng: Watch this video to see how.

media_transcript.eng:
Joining your child in their world means giving them your full attention, and letting them lead. You don‚Äôt need a lot of time - even 10 minutes a day can make a big difference. Here‚Äôs how:
Make time to spend with your child one-on-one. Try to minimise distractions and interruptions.

Join your child in their world by getting down on your child‚Äôs level. Sit close to them to make it a shared experience.

Let your child decide what to play and how to play. Don‚Äôt try to change what they are doing or instruct them. Instead, follow their lead. 

During the activity, observe and listen. Pay attention to what your child is doing or saying. Be curious about what they might be thinking and feeling.   

Respond to what your child is doing with enthusiasm and praise. You could say: I see you are enjoying playing with these blocks. Wow! You are building such a tall and strong wall!

Joining your child in their world and giving them your full attention helps them feel close and connected to you. This helps you build a strong relationship with your child. A strong relationship with you will help them to have healthy relationships with others in the future.

rows.text_1: What could the father have done differently?

text_1.eng: What could the father have done differently?

text_2.eng: Good question! He could have let his child lead and used praise instead of criticism.

media_transcript.eng:
Why did the son feel discouraged and why did he walk away? 

Because the father was being critical and tried to change what his son was doing. 

Connecting with our children is not about telling them how they should be playing or what they are doing wrong. By following your child‚Äôs lead, showing that you are paying attention and responding with praise, you make your child feel important and connected to you. This builds their confidence and sets them up for success.

Looking for a quick and powerful connection activity? 

A great way to connect with your child is to look at a book together.

rows.text_2: Always try to respond to what your child is saying in a positive and enthusiastic way.

Instead of saying ‚Äúno!‚Äù or ‚Äúthat‚Äôs wrong!‚Äù, use praise and positive responses to encourage your child to keep learning.

If your child says something that‚Äôs wrong (like pointing to an apple and calling it a tomato) you don‚Äôt need to say ‚Äúhow can you think that?!‚Äù or ‚Äúthat‚Äôs wrong!‚Äù. 

Instead, you can ignore the mistake and respond with the correct name, saying: 
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs an apple. It‚Äôs red and round like a tomato, but it‚Äôs an apple‚Äù. Your child will learn more if they don‚Äôt feel criticised or discouraged
